title: How to Exercise While Using Your Computer

steps.headline: Hold your thumb 6 inches (15.2 cm) from your face.
steps.description: Focus on your thumb while you inhale. Focus on an object 10 feet (3.0 m) away while you exhale, and repeat 15 times to increase eye flexibility.

steps.headline: Keep your head straight, facing your computer screen.
steps.description: Scan the edges of your vision in a circle for 2 minutes. Breathe while you keep your eyes moving around the room in a fluid motion.

steps.headline: Relax your eyes every few hours.
steps.description:
Place cupped hands in front of your eyes, making sure the palms do not directly touch the eyes. Stare into your palms for 20 to 30 seconds, until your vision becomes darker. When you see almost complete darkness, you will know your eyes are relaxed and you can continue. Studies have shown that eyestrain and visual stress place you at a risk for glaucoma. A few eye exercises or resting periods each day can help to reduce the risk. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/b2\/Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-4Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/b2\/Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-4Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Look over your right shoulder.
steps.description:
Lower your neck so that it almost sits on your right shoulder. Breathe deeply and roll your neck from your right shoulder, past your collarbone to the left shoulder. Repeat this exercise 10 to 20 times in a slow, fluid motion. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/4f\/Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-5Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/4f\/Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-5Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Raise your feet onto your toes simultaneously, without your shoes on if possible.
steps.description: Allow the toes to curl until they are at a right angle to your feet. Hold for 10 seconds and repeat if necessary.

steps.headline: Breathe deeply and begin to do shoulder circles, moving in a clockwise motion.
steps.description: Repeat the motion for 15 seconds and then switch to a counter-clockwise motion.

steps.headline: Place your arms at your sides.
steps.description:
Breathe deeply and raise them slowly until they are straight up in the air. Raise 1 hand a time, as if you are trying to pick apples of a tree, then lower it and raise your opposite arm. Repeat 10 times with each arm before slowly lowering them to the ground. On the last 2 repetitions, when you are done with your "apple pickers," lean back in your chair. Gently arch your back and take your arms back as far as they can go. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/5\/50\/Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-8Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-8Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/5\/50\/Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-8Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-8Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Do wrist circles for 20 seconds, turning them clockwise and counter-clockwise.
steps.description: Place your palm down and push down gently on the top of the wrist with the other hand for 10 seconds. Place your palm face up and push gently on the tops of your fingers with the other hand.

steps.headline: Breathe deeply and then squeeze your gluteal (buttock) muscles.
steps.description:
You should sit slightly higher in your desk as you tighten the muscles for 10 seconds. Relax and repeat 10 times. If possible, do these exercises 3 or more times per day to noticeably firm your muscles and improve your posture. Try to do this list of exercises throughout the day, devoting more time and repetitions to your weaker muscles. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/4b\/Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-10Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-10Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/4b\/Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-10Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-10Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Sit straight up and flex your core muscles.
steps.description: With your hands typing or resting on the keyboard, squeeze your shoulder blades together for 3 seconds. Relax for 1 second and repeat 10 times.

steps.headline: Replace your desk chair with an exercise ball of equal height as your chair.
steps.description:
Sit on the ball with your back straight and your feet hip width apart, a few inches away from the ball. Do this for 10 to 20 minutes at a time, and then return to your desk chair, to avoid injury from overworked muscles. Overuse of an exercise ball as a desk chair can do more harm than good. Core muscles need to be engaged for short periods and then rested. Tired muscles can lead to bad posture or a muscle imbalance. Try to use the ball for 3 periods of 10 minutes each day, and slowly work up to using it for a longer period of time. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/9d\/Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-12Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-12Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/9d\/Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-12Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-12Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Place your palms on your forehead.
steps.description: Push your head against your palms, as your palms resist the motion. Hold for 10 seconds.

steps.headline: Place your palms on the back of your neck.
steps.description: Push your head backwards against your palms, as they resist for 10 seconds. Repeat this exercise 3 to 5 times to tone your neck muscles.

steps.headline: Do a gentle twist to engage your core and stretch your back.
steps.description:
Sit up straight in your chair, and then slowly place your right hand on the right corner of your chair. Slowly twist your body for 15 seconds, trying to place your left hand on top of your right hand. Return to the straight forward position and repeat the twist on the left side. Do this 2 times, or whenever you are feeling tension in your back throughout the day. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/8\/89\/Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-15Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-15Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/8\/89\/Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-15Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-15Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Sit in your chair and use your arms to pull your right knee as close to your chest as possible.
steps.description: Hold the position and lift your left leg off the ground until it is straight. Hold this position for 15 to 30 seconds and then switch legs, repeating 3 to 10 times.

steps.headline: Keep 2 to 5 lb.
steps.description: (0.9 to 2.3 kg) weights near your computer. When you are reading a document or talking on the phone, do bicep curls, arm-flys and/or or tricep dips. This will increase arm strength and reduce muscle tension.

text:
Desk/Computer Stretches Hold your thumb 6 inches (15.2 cm) from your face. Focus on your thumb while you inhale. Focus on an object 10 feet (3.0 m) away while you exhale, and repeat 15 times to increase eye flexibility. Keep your head straight, facing your computer screen. Scan the edges of your vision in a circle for 2 minutes. Breathe while you keep your eyes moving around the room in a fluid motion. Relax your eyes every few hours. Place cupped hands in front of your eyes, making sure the palms do not directly touch the eyes. Stare into your palms for 20 to 30 seconds, until your vision becomes darker. When you see almost complete darkness, you will know your eyes are relaxed and you can continue. Studies have shown that eyestrain and visual stress place you at a risk for glaucoma. A few eye exercises or resting periods each day can help to reduce the risk. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b2/Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-4Bullet1.jpg/v4-459px-Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b2/Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-4Bullet1.jpg/v4-759px-Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Look over your right shoulder. Lower your neck so that it almost sits on your right shoulder. Breathe deeply and roll your neck from your right shoulder, past your collarbone to the left shoulder. Repeat this exercise 10 to 20 times in a slow, fluid motion. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4f/Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-5Bullet1.jpg/v4-459px-Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4f/Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-5Bullet1.jpg/v4-759px-Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Raise your feet onto your toes simultaneously, without your shoes on if possible. Allow the toes to curl until they are at a right angle to your feet. Hold for 10 seconds and repeat if necessary. Breathe deeply and begin to do shoulder circles, moving in a clockwise motion. Repeat the motion for 15 seconds and then switch to a counter-clockwise motion. Place your arms at your sides. Breathe deeply and raise them slowly until they are straight up in the air. Raise 1 hand a time, as if you are trying to pick apples of a tree, then lower it and raise your opposite arm. Repeat 10 times with each arm before slowly lowering them to the ground. On the last 2 repetitions, when you are done with your "apple pickers," lean back in your chair. Gently arch your back and take your arms back as far as they can go. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/50/Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-8Bullet1.jpg/v4-459px-Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-8Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/50/Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-8Bullet1.jpg/v4-759px-Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-8Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Do wrist circles for 20 seconds, turning them clockwise and counter-clockwise. Place your palm down and push down gently on the top of the wrist with the other hand for 10 seconds. Place your palm face up and push gently on the tops of your fingers with the other hand. Desk/Computer Exercises Breathe deeply and then squeeze your gluteal (buttock) muscles. You should sit slightly higher in your desk as you tighten the muscles for 10 seconds. Relax and repeat 10 times. If possible, do these exercises 3 or more times per day to noticeably firm your muscles and improve your posture. Try to do this list of exercises throughout the day, devoting more time and repetitions to your weaker muscles. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4b/Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-10Bullet1.jpg/v4-459px-Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-10Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4b/Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-10Bullet1.jpg/v4-759px-Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-10Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Sit straight up and flex your core muscles. With your hands typing or resting on the keyboard, squeeze your shoulder blades together for 3 seconds. Relax for 1 second and repeat 10 times. Replace your desk chair with an exercise ball of equal height as your chair. Sit on the ball with your back straight and your feet hip width apart, a few inches away from the ball. Do this for 10 to 20 minutes at a time, and then return to your desk chair, to avoid injury from overworked muscles. Overuse of an exercise ball as a desk chair can do more harm than good. Core muscles need to be engaged for short periods and then rested. Tired muscles can lead to bad posture or a muscle imbalance. Try to use the ball for 3 periods of 10 minutes each day, and slowly work up to using it for a longer period of time. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9d/Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-12Bullet1.jpg/v4-459px-Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-12Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9d/Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-12Bullet1.jpg/v4-759px-Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-12Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Place your palms on your forehead. Push your head against your palms, as your palms resist the motion. Hold for 10 seconds. Place your palms on the back of your neck. Push your head backwards against your palms, as they resist for 10 seconds. Repeat this exercise 3 to 5 times to tone your neck muscles. Do a gentle twist to engage your core and stretch your back. Sit up straight in your chair, and then slowly place your right hand on the right corner of your chair. Slowly twist your body for 15 seconds, trying to place your left hand on top of your right hand. Return to the straight forward position and repeat the twist on the left side. Do this 2 times, or whenever you are feeling tension in your back throughout the day. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/89/Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-15Bullet1.jpg/v4-459px-Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-15Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/89/Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-15Bullet1.jpg/v4-759px-Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-15Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Sit in your chair and use your arms to pull your right knee as close to your chest as possible. Hold the position and lift your left leg off the ground until it is straight. Hold this position for 15 to 30 seconds and then switch legs, repeating 3 to 10 times. Keep 2 to 5 lb. (0.9 to 2.3 kg) weights near your computer. When you are reading a document or talking on the phone, do bicep curls, arm-flys and/or or tricep dips. This will increase arm strength and reduce muscle tension.
sentences: Desk\/Computer Stretches Hold your thumb 6 inches (15.2 cm) from your face.
Focus on your thumb while you inhale.
Focus on an object 10 feet (3.0 m) away while you exhale, and repeat 15 times to increase eye flexibility.
Keep your head straight, facing your computer screen.
Scan the edges of your vision in a circle for 2 minutes.
Breathe while you keep your eyes moving around the room in a fluid motion.
Relax your eyes every few hours.
Place cupped hands in front of your eyes, making sure the palms do not directly touch the eyes.
Stare into your palms for 20 to 30 seconds, until your vision becomes darker.
When you see almost complete darkness, you will know your eyes are relaxed and you can continue.
Studies have shown that eyestrain and visual stress place you at a risk for glaucoma.
A few eye exercises or resting periods each day can help to reduce the risk.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/b2\/Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-4Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/b2\/Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-4Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Look over your right shoulder.
Lower your neck so that it almost sits on your right shoulder.
Breathe deeply and roll your neck from your right shoulder, past your collarbone to the left shoulder.
Repeat this exercise 10 to 20 times in a slow, fluid motion.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/4f\/Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-5Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/4f\/Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-5Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Raise your feet onto your toes simultaneously, without your shoes on if possible.
Allow the toes to curl until they are at a right angle to your feet.
Hold for 10 seconds and repeat if necessary.
Breathe deeply and begin to do shoulder circles, moving in a clockwise motion.
Repeat the motion for 15 seconds and then switch to a counter-clockwise motion.
Place your arms at your sides.
Breathe deeply and raise them slowly until they are straight up in the air.
Raise 1 hand a time, as if you are trying to pick apples of a tree, then lower it and raise your opposite arm.
Repeat 10 times with each arm before slowly lowering them to the ground.
On the last 2 repetitions, when you are done with your "apple pickers," lean back in your chair.
Gently arch your back and take your arms back as far as they can go.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/5\/50\/Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-8Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-8Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/5\/50\/Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-8Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-8Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Do wrist circles for 20 seconds, turning them clockwise and counter-clockwise.
Place your palm down and push down gently on the top of the wrist with the other hand for 10 seconds.
Place your palm face up and push gently on the tops of your fingers with the other hand.
Desk\/Computer Exercises Breathe deeply and then squeeze your gluteal (buttock) muscles.
You should sit slightly higher in your desk as you tighten the muscles for 10 seconds.
Relax and repeat 10 times.
If possible, do these exercises 3 or more times per day to noticeably firm your muscles and improve your posture.
Try to do this list of exercises throughout the day, devoting more time and repetitions to your weaker muscles.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/4b\/Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-10Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-10Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/4b\/Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-10Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-10Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Sit straight up and flex your core muscles.
With your hands typing or resting on the keyboard, squeeze your shoulder blades together for 3 seconds.
Relax for 1 second and repeat 10 times.
Replace your desk chair with an exercise ball of equal height as your chair.
Sit on the ball with your back straight and your feet hip width apart, a few inches away from the ball.
Do this for 10 to 20 minutes at a time, and then return to your desk chair, to avoid injury from overworked muscles.
Overuse of an exercise ball as a desk chair can do more harm than good.
Core muscles need to be engaged for short periods and then rested.
Tired muscles can lead to bad posture or a muscle imbalance.
Try to use the ball for 3 periods of 10 minutes each day, and slowly work up to using it for a longer period of time.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/9d\/Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-12Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-12Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/9d\/Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-12Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-12Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Place your palms on your forehead.
Push your head against your palms, as your palms resist the motion.
Hold for 10 seconds.
Place your palms on the back of your neck.
Push your head backwards against your palms, as they resist for 10 seconds.
Repeat this exercise 3 to 5 times to tone your neck muscles.
Do a gentle twist to engage your core and stretch your back.
Sit up straight in your chair, and then slowly place your right hand on the right corner of your chair.
Slowly twist your body for 15 seconds, trying to place your left hand on top of your right hand.
Return to the straight forward position and repeat the twist on the left side.
Do this 2 times, or whenever you are feeling tension in your back throughout the day.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/8\/89\/Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-15Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-15Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/8\/89\/Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-15Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Exercise-While-Using-Your-Computer-Step-15Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Sit in your chair and use your arms to pull your right knee as close to your chest as possible.
Hold the position and lift your left leg off the ground until it is straight.
Hold this position for 15 to 30 seconds and then switch legs, repeating 3 to 10 times.
Keep 2 to 5 lb.
(0.9 to 2.3 kg) weights near your computer.
When you are reading a document or talking on the phone, do bicep curls, arm-flys and/or or tricep dips.
This will increase arm strength and reduce muscle tension.
